title: Closet
data:
In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, a **closet**, also known as a **niche**, is a single square that is often located behind a [door](/wiki/Door "Door") or wall.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 Variants](#Variants)

  - [3.1 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [3.2 xNetHack](#xNetHack)

- [4 References](#References)

## Description

Closets are only created in ordinary rooms that are generated as part of a room-and-corridors map at level creation. Monsters can be generated inside closets just like on any other square.

6⁄7 of closets will have a door leading into them, with 4⁄5 of doors created this way being [secret doors](/wiki/Secret_door "Secret door"). If a closet is created with no door, there is a 1⁄5 chance that the [wall](/wiki/Wall "Wall") blocking the closet is replaced with [iron bars](/wiki/Iron_bars "Iron bars"), and a separate 2⁄3 chance of a [@](/wiki/Human_or_elf "Human or elf") [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") being generated in the closet[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) - the closet will also have a [scroll of teleportation](/wiki/Scroll_of_teleportation "Scroll of teleportation") if it is not generated on a [no-teleport level](/wiki/No-teleport_level "No-teleport level"), and has a 1⁄3 chance of containing an additional random item.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) The scroll is present to ensure that a character teleported into such a closet can escape if they lack any other means of doing so, though it is also possible to dig into or out of them unless the level is [undiggable](/wiki/Undiggable "Undiggable"); the closet may also be connected to a corridor, allowing normal access.

Some closets can be generated with a [teleportation trap](/wiki/Teleportation_trap "Teleportation trap") that points to a [vault](/wiki/Vault "Vault"), and others can have a [level teleporter](/wiki/Level_teleporter "Level teleporter") or a [trap door](/wiki/Trap_door "Trap door") - the former two closet types will have a faded [engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") of **ad aerarium** (from the Latin "to the treasure") in the dust outside, while the latter will have a faded engraving of **[Vlad](/wiki/Vlad_the_Impaler "Vlad the Impaler") was here** instead. The presence of a level teleporter in an "ad aerarium" closet is a [pun](/wiki/Pun "Pun") on a supposed secondary meaning of "aerarium" as sky.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

## Strategy

Lockable closets can be used as a "safe area" to test certain items or rest via [.](/wiki/Dot "Dot") to recover [HP](/wiki/HP "HP"). They can also be used for various other purposes, e.g. farming for [dragon scales](/wiki/Dragon_scales "Dragon scales") to create [dragon scale mail](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail").

## Variants

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), a [skull](/wiki/Skull "Skull") may be generated inside an inaccessible closet instead of a corpse.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), if a [thiefstone](/wiki/Thiefstone "Thiefstone") steals an item from you but there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") available on the level, it will find an accessible closet to teleport itself and the item to.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 451](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L451): *"place\_niche"*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 529](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L529)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 531](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L531)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 536](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L536)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 539](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L539)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) This does not appear to be an actual secondary meaning - it may be an error on the part of the [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam"), which could be due to confusion between the prefixes *aes-* relating to money, from which 'aerarium' derives, and *aer-*, which relates to air/sky/flight.

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Closet

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In NetHack, a closet, also known as a niche, is a single square that is often located behind a door or wall.[1]

Contents

  • 1 Description
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Variants
    • 3.1 SporkHack
    • 3.2 xNetHack
  • 4 References

Description

Closets are only created in ordinary rooms that are generated as part of a room-and-corridors map at level creation. Monsters can be generated inside closets just like on any other square.

6⁄7 of closets will have a door leading into them, with 4⁄5 of doors created this way being secret doors. If a closet is created with no door, there is a 1⁄5 chance that the wall blocking the closet is replaced with iron bars, and a separate 2⁄3 chance of a @ corpse being generated in the closet[2][3] - the closet will also have a scroll of teleportation if it is not generated on a no-teleport level, and has a 1⁄3 chance of containing an additional random item.[4][5] The scroll is present to ensure that a character teleported into such a closet can escape if they lack any other means of doing so, though it is also possible to dig into or out of them unless the level is undiggable; the closet may also be connected to a corridor, allowing normal access.

Some closets can be generated with a teleportation trap that points to a vault, and others can have a level teleporter or a trap door - the former two closet types will have a faded engraving of ad aerarium (from the Latin "to the treasure") in the dust outside, while the latter will have a faded engraving of Vlad was here instead. The presence of a level teleporter in an "ad aerarium" closet is a pun on a supposed secondary meaning of "aerarium" as sky.[6]

Strategy

Lockable closets can be used as a "safe area" to test certain items or rest via . to recover HP. They can also be used for various other purposes, e.g. farming for dragon scales to create dragon scale mail.

Variants

SporkHack

In SporkHack, a skull may be generated inside an inaccessible closet instead of a corpse.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, if a thiefstone steals an item from you but there is no chest available on the level, it will find an accessible closet to teleport itself and the item to.

References

  1. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 451: "place_niche"
  2. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 529
  3. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 531
  4. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 536
  5. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 539
  6. ↑ This does not appear to be an actual secondary meaning - it may be an error on the part of the DevTeam, which could be due to confusion between the prefixes aes- relating to money, from which 'aerarium' derives, and aer-, which relates to air/sky/flight.

rawPage: In ''[[NetHack]]'', a '''closet''', also known as a '''niche''', is a single square that is often located behind a [[door]] or wall.{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|451|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment="place_niche"}} ==Description== Closets are only created in ordinary rooms that are generated as part of a room-and-corridors map at level creation. Monsters can be generated inside closets just like on any other square. {{frac|6|7}} of closets will have a door leading into them, with {{frac|4|5}} of doors created this way being [[secret door]]s. If a closet is created with no door, there is a {{frac|5}} chance that the [[wall]] blocking the closet is replaced with [[iron bars]], and a separate {{frac|2|3}} chance of a {{mcsl|@}} [[corpse]] being generated in the closet{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|529|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|531|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} - the closet will also have a [[scroll of teleportation]] if it is not generated on a [[no-teleport level]], and has a {{frac|3}} chance of containing an additional random item.{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|536|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|539|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} The scroll is present to ensure that a character teleported into such a closet can escape if they lack any other means of doing so, though it is also possible to dig into or out of them unless the level is [[undiggable]]; the closet may also be connected to a corridor, allowing normal access. Some closets can be generated with a [[teleportation trap]] that points to a [[vault]], and others can have a [[level teleporter]] or a [[trap door]] - the former two closet types will have a faded [[engraving]] of '''ad aerarium''' (from the Latin "to the treasure") in the dust outside, while the latter will have a faded engraving of '''[[Vlad the Impaler|Vlad]] was here''' instead. The presence of a level teleporter in an "ad aerarium" closet is a [[pun]] on a supposed secondary meaning of "aerarium" as sky.This does not appear to be an actual secondary meaning - it may be an error on the part of the [[DevTeam]], which could be due to confusion between the prefixes aes- relating to money, from which 'aerarium' derives, and aer-, which relates to air/sky/flight. ==Strategy== Lockable closets can be used as a "safe area" to test certain items or rest via {{kbd|.}} to recover [[HP]]. They can also be used for various other purposes, e.g. farming for [[dragon scales]] to create [[dragon scale mail]]. ==Variants== ===SporkHack=== In [[SporkHack]], a [[skull]] may be generated inside an inaccessible closet instead of a corpse. ===xNetHack=== In [[xNetHack]], if a [[thiefstone]] steals an item from you but there is no [[chest]] available on the level, it will find an accessible closet to teleport itself and the item to. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Dungeon features]]
